1:40 - Got some THICC bodily fluids, there!
I have had a capsule endoscopy (I have enteritis), it was far less hassle than a colonoscopy and endoscopy. You just had to monitor what you ate and drank while the device was recording.

I've always imagined that internal medical Nanobots would use Biomimicry, though my own concept was more like a súú tiny Squid-bot which would use it's mantle fins in either saggitate or skirt-like configurations (whatever works best for the viscosity of the fluids it would functioning in) to move, while carrying sensory & manipulatory systems (in a closed configuration) behind it, much like a squids tentacles.

• Independently bots having only limited intelligence, but in swarms of hundreds/thousands of networked individuals, being capable of some incredible feats.

• Having chemo-sensors to help it navigate (much like a single-celled organism). Optical cameras may not function particularly well at those scales due to the optical wave size of visual light, but may still have a use in some circumstances.

• Having myriad varieties of forms/configurations (at differing scales) for different jobs within the body: such as a needle & syringe to administer medications at precise locations, or a group of manipulators to capture pathogens, perhaps even an internal library of Cytokines / RNA Messenger Fragments / Hormones / etc. to trigger Epigenetic responses in certain cells.

• Powering their internal systems would, of course, be a major challenge, however I suspect that a combination of an onboard hydrogen battery &/or perhaps a secondary chemical sugar system for more energetic functions.

• Their bodies constructed of a soft pseudo-muscular polymer, over a semi-rigid internal carbon/silicate skeleton.

All in all, the potential for various types of medical Nano;bots is truly extraordinary & these preliminary experiments are providing essential data for their eventual development.

Dear SciShow,

You have missed mentioning two of the most advanced tiny robots. Please see below:


1. A flexible microsystem capable of controlled motion and actuation by wireless power transfer
(https://doi.org/10.1038/s41928-020-0384-1); (https://www.youtube.com/watch?app=desktop&v=G2mA0i_xEmU&ab_channel=TUChemnitz)


2. Electronically integrated, mass-manufactured, microscopic robots
(https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-020-2626-9)



They are the most advanced mini bots that can integrate microelectronic components and can be steered wirelessly
